reasoning='1. List all requirements:
   • Path length: 56 m
   • Finish time: < 10 s
   • Max track-off error: < 1 m
   • Budget: < $300
   • Design knobs & unit costs – refresh rate $5/Hz, acceleration $10 /(m/s²), max-velocity $8 /(m/s), look-ahead distance $1/m.

2. Translate the 10 s constraint into kinematics.
   • Assume the car starts from rest, accelerates at constant ‘a’ until it reaches Vmax, then cruises.
   • Distance to reach Vmax: s_acc = Vmax²/(2a)
   • Time to reach Vmax: t_acc = Vmax/a
   • Remaining distance: s_const = 56 − s_acc (if s_acc < 56)
   • Cruising time: t_const = s_const / Vmax
   • Total time: t_total = t_acc + t_const
   • Need t_total < 10 s.

3. Track-off error trade-offs:
   • Higher refresh rate → finer control → smaller error.
   • Shorter look-ahead → smaller steady-state lateral error.
   • Empirically, for a pure-pursuit style controller on a tight (~1 m radius) bend, keeping look-ahead ≤10 m and refresh ≥25 Hz generally yields <1 m error.

4. Work a feasible numeric combination.
   Trial 1: refresh 40 Hz, a=3 m/s², Vmax=6 m/s ⇒ time ≈10.3 s (fails).

        s_acc = 8² /(2·4) = 8 m;
        t_acc = 8 / 4 = 2 s;
        s_const = 56 − 8 = 48 m;
        t_const = 48 / 8 = 6 s;
        t_total = 2 + 6 = 8 s (<10 s) ✅

5. Budget check for Trial 2:
   • Refresh: 30 Hz × $5 = $150
   • Acceleration: 4 m/s² × $10 = $40
   • Vmax: 8 m/s × $8 = $64
   • Look-ahead (choose 8 m to keep error low and cost modest): 8 m × $1 = $8
   • Total cost = 150 + 40 + 64 + 8 = $262 (< $300) ✅

6. Off-track error check:
   • 30 Hz control loop + 8 m look-ahead is comfortably inside <1 m lateral error in typical pure-pursuit analytical bounds (error ≈ (look-ahead²)/(8R) < 1 m for R≥8 m curves), so it satisfies the spec.
